column4: Scenario
column5: Expected Results
column8: Comments

column4: Receive the entirety of a PO (Happy Path)
column5: Stock Units are created in the receiving location with proper quantities

column4: Receive part of a PO line
column5: Order line status goes into a  'Partial Receipt' status

column4: Receive a quantity greater than what is asked for on the PO
column5: No errors are thrown and the number received is correcty populated on the received pack quantity field on the order line and all stock appears in the receiving location.

column4: Receive a quantity greater than what is asked for on the PO but not twice as much
column5: No errors are thrown and the number received is correcty populated on the received pack quantity field on the order line and all stock appears in the receiving location.

column4: Receive a quantity greater than what is asked for on the PO but also more than twice as much
column5: Error "You can only receive up to the max amount X of Each." is thrown and user is not able to continue

column4: Receive an item that is not on the Purchase Order
column5: No errors are thrown and a new order line is created with the item received and all stock appears in the receiving location.

column4: Receive a PO with a receiving note attached
column5: After the purchase order entry screen the note is displayed to the user

column4: Receive Shortages
Receive a Blind Order
column5: An order with the type of 'Blind Receipt' is created and all items received show up as order lines with the accurate received pack quantities and all stock appears in the receiving location.

column4: Unreceive a portion of a PO
column5: Order line status and receive quantity change accordingly

column4: Receive by inbound LPN and sort to pallet
Create Customer Return (RMA) within Deposco
Receive a Return
column5: An order with the type of 'Blind RMA' is created and all items received show up as order lines with the accurate received pack quantities and all stock appears in the returns location.

column4: Suggested Putaway locations from receiving (Warehouse Putaway)
column5: Suggested locations appear as expected (1 consolidate/empty home location, 5 empty locations without storage records)

column5: No errors and stock is correctly putaway to the specified location

column4: Put stock away using the Warehouse Putaway process by scanning the location's barcode
column5: No errors and stock is correctly putaway to the specified location

column4: Put stock away into a location that does not appear in the suggest list box
column5: No errors and stock is correctly putaway to the specified location

column4: Put part of the stock into Damages and the other stock into a suggested location
column5: No errors and stock is correctly putaway to the specified location

column4: Put "New" stock away into an empty bin location and select the 'Create Storage Record' box
column5: Item now has storage details in location putaway

column4: Total: 10
Suggested Putaway locations from returns (Returns Putaway)
column5: Suggested locations appear as expected (Either the aisle Bin location or the stocked out bin location)

column4: Suggested Putaway
Put stock away using the Returns Putaway process by selecting the location from the list box
column5: No errors and stock is correctly putaway to the specified location

column4: Put stock away using the Returns Putaway process by scanning the Isle Bin's barcode
column5: No errors and stock is correctly putaway to the specified location

column4: Inventory General Ledger
column8: IGL inventory view is able to be used to see each transaction that increases or decreases inventory by item

column4: View Inventory Available to Release
column8: Warehouse on hand inventory minus allocated minus unpickable minus damaged

column4: View Kit Available to Promise Inventory
column8: For bundled products that are composed of multiple individual items, the quantity of an item that can be sold from using components to make the finished good

column4: Look up inventory by Item in the UI
column8: Ability to see inventory by item within the stock unit portion of the solution UI

column4: Look up inventory by LPN in the UI
column8: Ability to see inventory by LPN (container) within the stock unit portion of the solution UI

column4: Look up inventory by Location in the UI
column8: Ability to see inventory by location within the stock unit portion of the solution UI

column4: Look up inventory by Location Zone in the UI
column8: Ability to see inventory by zone within the stock unit portion of the solution UI

column4: Look up inventory by Location in the Handheld
column8: Warehouse Lookup process can be utilized on the handheld app to scan/enter Location and view inventory in that location

column4: Look up inventory by Item in the Handheld
column8: Warehouse Lookup process can be utilized on the handheld app to scan/enter Item and view inventory for that item in the warehouse

column4: Generate a cycle count task using the Cycle Count by Location PAL
column5: A task generates for that location

column4: Generate a cycle count task using the Last Couted Date scheduler
column5: 20 Cycle count tasks generate

column4: Lot Number Tracking
column8: Ability to capture Lot Number during receiving or inventory creation. Lot number is stored on the stock unit record.

column4: Generate a cycle count task with an exception
column5: A task generates for that location

column4: Count a cycle count task with no variance (Happy Path)
column5: The locations stock does not change

column4: Count a cycle count task with a variance
column5: The user is prompted to enter in a quantity for the second time, the stock in the location is updated the variance quantity

column4: Complete a count with no variance using the On Demand Cycle Count process
column5: The locations stock does not change

column4: Complete a count with no variance using the On Demand Cycle Count process
column5: The user is prompted to enter in a quantity for the second time, the stock in the location is updated the variance quantity

column4: View Kit Bill of Material in the UI
column8: This allows a user to see the "components" that make up a finished good within the Deposco UI. A Bill of Materials is a list of the components and quantities needed to assemble a finished good product.

column4: Kit to Stock: Assemble Kit and putaway to Stock
column8: Kit to Stock is used for a pre-assembly flow where a finished good needs to be assembled or built before it can be stocked and allocated against customer sales orders.

column4: Kit to Order
column8: If Kits do not need to be pre-built before picking, then Kit to Order functionality can be utilized. During wave release, if there are no stock units available for the Kit SKU, the component SKUs will be allocated for picking.

column4: Supervisor Review for approval, rejection, adjustment of cycle count variances
column8: When adjustments are made to stock unit records via the cycle count process, the adjustments can be placed in an approval queue before being committed, OR they can be automatically applied after process completion.

column4: Generate Cycle Count Task as result of Exception Pick
column8: When a pick task is exceptioned, a cycle count task can be created automatically for a user to cycle count the location.

column4: Generate System Directed Cycle Count tasks by Item or Location
column8: Warehouse supervisors can configure Deposco to automatically generate cycle count tasks on a scheduled basis for either items or locations.

column4: Create Manual Cycle Count Task for Location
column8: Supported by using Create Cycle Count (PAL), which can be triggered via UI or handheld device.

column4: On Demand Location Cycle Count
column8: Locations can by cycle counted on demand without a cycle count task being created.

column4: Start and Stop a Physical Count
column8: Process is used to Start a physical count or to Stop the users from doing a physical inventory count

column4: Adjust out all inventory in a location
column5: All stock units in the location are decremented. Values in the inventory ledger are accurate

column4: Adjust out a quantity of 1 item in a location
column5: The stock unit in the location is decremented by 1. Values in the inventory ledger are accurate

column4: Add a reason to an inventory adjustment
column5: The reason correctly populates in the inventory ledger

column4: Add a note to an inventory adjustment
column5: The note correctly populates in the inventory ledger

column4: Add stock to a Location
column5: A new stock unit is created in the location adjusted

column4: Move part of a stock quantity from one location to another using Move Item
column5: Stock is accurately moved from one location to the next

column4: Move items from one location to another using Move Item and selecting the 'Create Storage Record' checkbox
column5: Stock is accurately moved from one location to the next and storage details are deleted in the original location and created in the destination location

column4: Cancel Outbound Orders using Deposco's Cancel Order process
column8:
Sales orders can be canceled in Deposco from either the desktop UI using a process action link or from the handheld device using a cancel order process button. The following use cases are supported;
 Cancel Order
 Cancel Order Line(s)
 Cancel Partial Quantities on Order Line
 Cancel Remaining Order Lines for an Order

column4: Cancel Outbound Order via Integration from another system
column8:
With certain developed integrations, Deposco can accept order cancellations that originate and are sent from another system. When this is supported, the cancellations can only occur if the order has yet to be allocated.
 *Support of this must be confirmed specific to each integration

column4: View Orders based on certain criteria
column8:
Filters can be created in Deposco to view orders that meet a certain criteria. Some examples include:
 View orders by status
 View orders by source
 View orders by expected or actual ship date
 View orders with backordered product

column4: Manually build and release pick waves
column8: You can manually build and release a pick wave either by using a process action link (PAL) or by selecting an option on the handheld menu. When you manually build and release a pick wave by using a PAL, you select the orders that you want to evaluate for the pick wave. When you manually build and release a pick wave from the handheld menu, the workflow process evaluates all eligible orders.

column4: Undo Released Pick Wave
column8: After a wave has been built and released, you can undo the pick wave before picking has begun.

column4: Order Release - Backorder Policy - All stock on order to fulfill (no partial release)
column8: Stock must be available to completely fulfill all order lines for an order. Otherwise, the order and its order lines are back-ordered. If stock is available to fulfill other orders on the pick wave, then those orders are released. Only orders that cannot be completely fulfilled are back-ordered.

column4: Manually wave an International wave
column5: Wave is created and in released status, all orders on wave are released

column4: Order Release - Order Close Policy - Don't close if backordered
column8: The shortage quantity is reflected in the Shortage Pack Quantity field for the order line, the status of the order line moves to Partial Released, and the status of the order header moves to Back Ordered. The order can then be included on a different pick wave and fulfilled.

column4: Manually wave an Insured wave
column5: Wave is created and in released status, all orders on wave are released

column4: Wave kit orders of assembled kits (Kit to Stock)
column8: When kit items are on a customer sales order, Deposco will attempt to allocate the completed kit first. If no stock is available for the completed kit, Deposco will look to allocate the components of that kit. If you ONLY want to pick completed kits for an item, the "Kit to Stock Only" setting can be enabled on that kit item to prevent components from being allocated.

column4: Wave order for components of a kit (Kit to Order)
column8: Only needed if the "kit to order" flow is being utilized to allocate and fulfill component inventory for a kit item on a customer sales order. Note: For kit component allocation, order can be released on wave if partial can be fulfilled but only when there is enough inventory to make a full finished product (no partial kits will be released).

column4: Manually wave a Boxed wave
column5: Wave is created and in released status, all orders on wave are released

column4: Order release stock allocation (pick strategy) - based on Stock age attributes
column8:
Determine which stock is allocated when stock is available in multiple locations based on Stock age attributes;
 FIFO – (First In First Out) 
 LIFO – (Last In First Out) 
 FEFO – (First Expiration First Out) 
 LEFO – (Last Expiration First Out) 
 Oldest Stock First
 Sort by FEFO within an expiration day threshold

column4: Manually wave an Priority Shipping wave
column5: Wave is created and in released status, all orders on wave are released

column4: Manually wave a Woolx and Hanks singles wave
column5: Wave is created and in released status, all orders on wave are released

column4: Manually wave a Woolx Upper multi wave
column5: Wave is created and in released status, all orders on wave are released

column4: Manually wave a Woolx lower multi wave
column5: Wave is created and in released status, all orders on wave are released

column4: Manually wave a Hanks multi wave
column5: Wave is created and in released status, all orders on wave are released

column4: Manually plan an identicals wave
column5: Wave is created and in planned status, all orders on wave are new

column4: Release identicals wave through scheduler
column5: Wave is released, all orders on wave are released

column4: Release identicals wave through wave pal
column5: Wave is released, all orders on wave are released

column4: Pick the entirety of a Singles wave (Happy Path)
column5: All stock is placed in Cart, no errors are shown and everything behaves as expected
column8: Woolx Lower Single_240401_10

column5: Location picked is placed on hold, order goes into a back ordered status, and a cycle count task is created

column4: Stage a singles cart because the cart is too full
column5: User is prompted for a new cart, no errors occur and user is able to continue picking into a new cart

column4: Stage a singles cart because the user needs to do another task
column5: User is prompted for a new cart, they can now back out of the process and select the same cart later
column8: Hanks Single_240401_20

column4: Suspend a task because the stock cannot be picked at that moment
column5: The task is now moved to the end of the queue, it is picked last

column5: no errors are thrown and process behaves as if the item had been scanned

column4: Picking exception: Skip a pick during picking and return later
column8: Pick tasks can be skipped during the picking process. After the remaining pick tasks for the work group are complete, you are prompted again to pick the item that you skipped.

column4: Picking exception: No stock in a location
column8: Picking exception can be raised from the picking screen when a picker identifies no stock in the location. Deposco can attempt to reallocate to another location, and also generate a cycle count task.

column4: Picking exception: Damaged stock in a location
column8: Picking exception can be raised from the picking screen when a picker identifies damaged stock in the location. Deposco can attempt to reallocate to another location, and also generate a cycle count task.

column4: Rollback order after picking
column8: You may decide to roll back an order if the order has been picked but has not yet shipped. You can roll back one order line at a time for each order. Depending on the configuration, the canceled stock can remain in the picking container, you can automatically stage the canceled stock to a specific default location, or you can require the user to select and scan a destination location for the canceled stock.

column4: Pick the entirety of a Hanks Multis wave (Happy Path)
column5: All stock is placed in accurate bins, no errors are shown and everything behaves as expected
column8: Hanks Multi_240401_12

column4: Ship for customer outside of system
column8: If any shipping carriers will be used that are NOT going to be integrated with Deposco, then the order can be set to "Ship Outside System"

column4: Single Scan Packing process - ability to scan items into one or multiple outbound containers
column8: Single scan packing is used to pack and ship items from an order after batch picking has occurred. During batch picking, a group of orders is picked at the same time and sorted into bins on carts or similar equipment. The items from an individual bin are then packed into a shipping container during single scan packing.

column4: Pick the entirety of a Woolx Upper Multis wave (Happy Path)
column5: All stock is placed in accurate bins, no errors are shown and everything behaves as expected, user is able to go up and select stock from upper locations accurately
column8: Woolx Upper Multi Small_240402_3

column4: Pick an item into a bin that has already been picked into
column5: An error is thrown not allowing the user to pick into that bin and asked to select another one
column8: Hanks Multi_240402_1

column4: Pick an item into a new bin when there is a suggested bin populated
column5: An error is thrown not allowing the user to pick into that bin and asked to pick into the suggested bin
column8: Hanks Multi_240402_1

column4: Single Container Packing process - pack & ship one order containers that have already been sorted
column8: This process is used to pack and ship containers that have already been sorted, and do not need to be split. This process can also be used if multiple orders were consolidated into a single container for a single shipment.

column4: Pick an order into multiple bins by selecting the New Bin button
column5: The suggested bin is removed and the user is able to pick into a new bin
column8: Hanks Multi_240402_1

column4: Repalletize
column8: This process allows for movement of inventory from one container to another between the picking and shipping steps.

column4: Build Pallet
column8: The build pallet process allows user to scan stock units onto an LPN/pallet/container

column4: Manage Outbound TL/LTL loads (trips) via Assign Trip to Container process. Scan pallet LPNs (containers) onto a load (trip).
column8: The AssignTrip process will be used to load final outbound containers onto a trip for freight orders. Trips in Deposco represent a trailer load. Pallets are scanned and assigned to a dock door. After all pallets are loaded, the trip can be “soft-closed,” creating the shipment record in Deposco. The Shipment Lines will not be created until the trip is “Hard-Closed,” through the ManualCloseTrip process.

column4: Exception a pick task in multis picking
column5: Location picked is placed on hold, order goes into a back ordered status, and a cycle count task is created
column8: Hanks Multi_240402_1

column5: User is exited from process, can use warehouse look up to determine wave, and wave is not visible to other users
column8: Hanks Multi_240402_1

column4: Pick an item using the manual pick check box
column5: no errors are thrown and process behaves as if the item had been scanned
column8: Hanks Multi_240402_1

column8: When an order is shipping via an integrated shipping carrier, Deposco can print the shipping labels for the order at the time of shipping.

column8: Deposco's Cartonization algorithm to be used

column4: Pack out a Indenticals cart with an intentional error
column5: Error file is generated, user instructs a manager, change is made and user is able to pack out

column4: Assign Documents/Reports to Printers
column8: A printer assignment specifies the printer that should be used to print a label or document for a resource (a resource is associated to a user).

column4: Setup and Manage Printers
column8: The two standard printers found at a warehouse are standard paper printers and label printers. Paper printers include both ink and laser printers, and label printers include ink, laser, and thermal printers. Once printers are configured, then they can be validated before being used with Deposco.

column4: Manage Printer Resources to dictate what users are eligible for printing certain documents
column8: Each user is assigned to a single resource. However, users can change their resource assignment to print in a different location. For example, a packing/shipping user might work at Packing Station 1 on Monday but at Packing Station 3 on Tuesday.

column4: Change a user's Printer Resource
column8: Users can change the resource that their account is assigned to by either editing the Resource field for their account profile or by using the handheld menu.

column4: Change a user's Zone
column8: The active zone for your user account determines the warehouse tasks that you can perform for workflow processes such as picking. Each user account can be assigned to multiple zones based on the zone assignment settings for the account, but can only be active in a single zone at a time.

column4: Create User Views and utilize the ability to copy User Views
column8: A view is a defined set of filters for an entity list that enables you to quickly limit the list to specific data. For example, you can create a view for the Order Header List to display only sales orders with a status of Complete that shipped by UPS Ground

column4: Manage User Application Menus (Left Side Bar Menu Structure)
column8: You can configure the application menus that appear in the left pane of the Deposco application - inclusive of renaming, reordering, and removing.

column4: Manage Users, User Groups, and Permissions
column8: User Groups enable you to assign access permissions to menus, report categories, and widget categories, and facilitate the process of managing permissions to applications, entities, and specific features or processes. Groups are typically created either for specific roles, such as administrators, or for functional areas, such as billing, inbound, or inventory.

column4: Define and Create Page Layouts
column8: A page layout defines the tabs, sections, and fields that appear on an entity detail page for an entity. You can create multiple layouts to view different information for an entity.

column4: Setup and Manage Shipping Services (Ship Vias)
column8: A shipping service determines how a package is going to be shipped and what documentation (such as a shipping label) needs to printed. An example would be UPS Ground.

column4: Setup and Support for International Shipping Services
column8: International shipping services are used to enable packages to be shipped across country borders, and require additional data as well as shipping documentation.

column4: Import or Create Trading Partners
column8: A trading partner in Deposco represents an external party to the company, either a supplier that provides products or services, or a customer that purchases products from the company.

column4: Import or Create Items, Packs and UPCs
column8:
An item, or stock keeping unit (SKU), is a distinct type of item for sale, including all attributes that distinguish the item type from other item types.
 Packs enable you to manage the stock of an item in multiple units of measure.

column4: Import or Create Kit Headers and Kit Details (Bill of Materials)
column8: A kit header is a parent record that identifies a kit that is built from items. Each kit header has one or more kit details, which describe the individual items that compose the kit.
